<url>http://gmane.org/img/gmane-25t.png</url>     <link>http://gmane.org</link>   </image>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/726">     <title>Question</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/726</link>     <description><pre>Is this a correct assumption?  The manual has a function to create a pixmap from a surface using this:  *AG_Pixmap ** AG_PixmapFromSurfaceNODUP (AG_Widget *parent, Uint flags, AG_Surface *src)  However, there is no AS_PixmapFromSurfaceNODUP. In the code, there is defined  AG_Pixamp *AG_PixmapFromSurfaceCopy() and a AG_Pixamp *AG_PixmapFromSurface() which seems to be the porper calls to use (former to copy, later to assign by reference).  Can I assume there isn't and will not be a PixmapFromSurfaceNODUP in the future and instead should use the two functions as defined in gui/pixmap.c?  Mick _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Jena and Mick</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-16T19:30:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/725">     <title>Custom cursor in AGAR</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/725</link>     <description><pre>Dell - Internal Use - Confidential Hi All,  I am using the SDL driver in AGAR for rendering. The SDL mouse cursor is flickering and on going through the documentation of SDL I found that It is a persistent problem.  *         So I decided to disable the default cursor (SDL_ShowCursor(SDL_DISABLE); )  *         Load a bmp image of cursor  and blit it at the current mouse position on the SDL screen.  *          To update the mouse cursor I fill the SDL screen with some color (SDL_FillRect(screen, NULL, 0x000000);)  This approach seems to work fine in SDL, but when I draw a AGAR window and then use the SDL screen to blit my mouse cursor on, the AGAR window disappears after the screen is updated on calling SDL_FillRect(screen, NULL, 0x000000)  If I don't clear the SDL screen then the AGAR window is displayed but it leaves a trail of the cursor (bmp) which is expected.  Could someone please help me with this?  Also is there a way to create the custom mouse cursor  the same way I have done in SDL?  How do I update the window I have attached the c file along with the  mail as well.  Thanks, Ritvik  #include &lt;agar/core.h&gt; #include &lt;agar/gui.h&gt; #include &lt;SDL/SDL_video.h&gt; #include &lt;SDL/SDL.h&gt; #include &lt;sys/types.h&gt; #include &lt;sys/stat.h&gt; #include &lt;fcntl.h&gt; #include &lt;sys/ioctl.h&gt; #include &lt;limits.h&gt; #include &lt;unistd.h&gt; #include &lt;assert.h&gt; #include &lt;string.h&gt; #include &lt;stdbool.h&gt; #include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;  #define WIDTH 1024 #define HEIGHT 768 #define BPP 4 #define DEPTH 32 int pressedKey = 0;/* Last pressed key */ int xClick = 0, yClick = 0;/* Last clicked x,y */ int curFPS = 0;/* Measured frame rate */ const int nominalFPS = 1000/30;/* Nominal frame rate */  SDL_Surface * screen; SDL_Surface * mouse; AG_Window *win; AG_Button *btn; AG_Surface *agbmp; AG_Surface *s;  bool running = true;  void draw(SDL_Surface * from, SDL_Surface * dest, int x, int y)  {     SDL_Rect rect;     rect.x = x;     rect.y = y;     if(from == NULL || dest == NULL) {         return;     }     SDL_BlitSurface(from, NULL, dest, &amp;rect);      }  void clearToColor(SDL_Surface * target, Uint32 color){     if (target == NULL) return;         SDL_FillRect (target, NULL, color);  }   void drawTransparant(SDL_Surface * from, SDL_Surface * dest, int x, int y) {     Uint32 colorkey = SDL_MapRGB(from-&gt;format, 0, 0, 255);     SDL_SetColorKey(from, SDL_SRCCOLORKEY, colorkey);     draw(from, dest, x, y);     SDL_SetColorKey(from, 0, 0);  }  SDL_Surface *loadSurface(char * file)  {     SDL_Surface * temp = NULL;     SDL_Surface * result = NULL;     if((temp = SDL_LoadBMP(file)) == NULL) {         printf("Failed to load file");         return NULL;     }     result = SDL_DisplayFormat(temp);     SDL_FreeSurface(temp);     return result; }  int init() {      if (AG_InitCore("agar-sdl-demo", 0) == -1)      {             printf("AG_InitCore: %s\ ", AG_GetError());         return 1;     }     if (SDL_Init(SDL_INIT_VIDEO) &lt; 0 )          return 1;     if(SDL_InitSubSystem(SDL_INIT_VIDEO) &lt; 0 ){         Print(L"Could not init subsystem");         return 1;     }     if (!(screen = SDL_SetVideoMode(WIDTH, HEIGHT, DEPTH, SDL_SWSURFACE)))     {         printf(L"Could not set video mode\ ");         SDL_Quit();         return 1;     }     if (AG_InitVideoSDL(screen, 0) == -1)      {         printf("%s\ ", AG_GetError());         AG_Destroy();         return 1;     }     //Load the cursor imaege     if ((mouse = loadSurface("ms_normal.bmp")) == NULL)     {         return 1;     }       AG_BindGlobalKey(AG_KEY_ESCAPE, AG_KEYMOD_ANY, AG_QuitGUI);      AG_BindGlobalKey(AG_KEY_F8, AG_KEYMOD_ANY, AG_ViewCapture);      win = AG_WindowNew(0);     AG_WindowSetPosition(win, AG_WINDOW_TR, 1);     AG_WindowSetCaption(win, "Agar Pane demo");     SDL_ShowCursor(SDL_DISABLE);     AG_WindowSetGeometry(win,-1,-1,1024,768);     AG_WindowShow(win);     return 0; }  //Render the mouse cursor on the screen.(This function is called from MyEventLoop whenever a mouse motion event is triggered.)  void render(int mouseX, int mouseY) {     clearToColor(screen,SDL_MapRGB(screen-&gt;format, 255, 0, 0));     drawTransparant(mouse, screen, mouseX, mouseY);     // flip screen at the end     SDL_Flip(screen);      if ((agbmp = AG_SurfaceFromSDL(screen)) != NULL) {         AG_PixmapFromSurface(win, 0, agbmp);     } else {         AG_LabelNewS(win, 0, AG_GetError());     }     }  static void MyEventLoop(void) {         AG_Driver *drv;         //AG_Window *win;         Uint32 t1, t2;         AG_DriverEvent dev;              t1 = AG_GetTicks();         for (;;) {             t2 = AG_GetTicks();                  if (t2-t1 &gt;= nominalFPS) {                 /*                  * Case 1: Update the video display.                  */                 AG_LockVFS(&amp;agDrivers);                      /* Render the Agar windows */                 if (agDriverSw) {                     /*                      * We are using a single-window driver                      * (e.g., sdlfb). If one of the windows is                      * marked dirty, all windows must be redrawn.                      */                     AG_FOREACH_WINDOW(win, agDriverSw) {                         if (win-&gt;dirty)                             break;                     }                     if (win != NULL) {                         AG_BeginRendering(agDriverSw);                         AG_FOREACH_WINDOW(win, agDriverSw) {                             if (!win-&gt;visible) {                                 continue;                             }                             AG_ObjectLock(win);                             AG_WindowDraw(win);                             AG_ObjectUnlock(win);                         }                         AG_EndRendering(agDriverSw);                     }                 } else {                     /*                      * We are using a multiple-window driver                      * (e.g., glx). Windows marked dirty are                      * redrawn.                      */                     AGOBJECT_FOREACH_CHILD(drv, &amp;agDrivers,                         ag_driver) {                         if (!AGDRIVER_MULTIPLE(drv)) {                             continue;                         }                         win = AGDRIVER_MW(drv)-&gt;win;                         if (!win-&gt;visible || !win-&gt;dirty) {                             continue;                         }                         AG_BeginRendering(drv);                         AG_ObjectLock(win);                         AG_WindowDraw(win);                         AG_ObjectUnlock(win);                         AG_EndRendering(drv);                     }                 }                 AG_UnlockVFS(&amp;agDrivers);                      t1 = AG_GetTicks();                 curFPS = nominalFPS - (t1-t2);                 if (curFPS &lt; 1) { curFPS = 1; }                  } else if (AG_PendingEvents(NULL) &gt; 0) {                 /*                  * Case 2: There are events waiting to be processed.                  */                 do {                     /* Retrieve the next queued event. */                     if (AG_GetNextEvent(NULL, &amp;dev) == 1) {                         switch (dev.type) {                         case AG_DRIVER_MOUSE_BUTTON_DOWN:                             xClick = dev.data.button.x;                             yClick = dev.data.button.y;                             printf("Click at %d,%d!\ ",                                 dev.data.button.x,                                 dev.data.button.y);                             break;                         case AG_DRIVER_MOUSE_MOTION:                              //render the cursor image at the current mouse coordinates.                              render(dev.data.motion.x,dev.data.motion.y);                                                            break;                         case AG_DRIVER_KEY_DOWN:                             pressedKey = (int)dev.data.key.ks;                             printf("Key down: %d (0x%x)\ ",                                 (int)dev.data.key.ks,                                 (Uint)dev.data.key.ucs);                             break;                         default:                             break;                         }                              /* Forward the event to Agar. */                         if (AG_ProcessEvent(NULL, &amp;dev) == -1)                             return;                     }                 } while (AG_PendingEvents(NULL) &gt; 0);                  } else if (AG_TIMEOUTS_QUEUED()) {                 /*                  * Case 3: There are AG_Timeout(3) callbacks to run.                  */                 AG_ProcessTimeouts(t2);             } else {                 /*                  * Case 4: Nothing to do, idle.                  */                 AG_Delay(1);             }         }     }         int main (int argc, char **argv) {        if (init() != 0) {         return -1;        }        MyEventLoop();        AG_Destroy();        return 0; }   _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Ritvik_Sharma-DYMqY+WieiM< at >public.gmane.org</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2014-08-20T06:28:02</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/724">     <title>Re: Unexpected rendering behavior with demo"customeventloop.c"</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/724</link>     <description><pre>Hi Antony,  That sounds awesome, I would like to hear more about this port. Agar  does work at its best with a native accelerated OpenGL.  Are you using a custom AG_Driver backend? Could you post the source code  for your event loop? If you see rendering artifacts or wrong font sizes,  it might be a GL state issue. You might also want to check that the  widget positioning and sizing is correct (the GUI debugger tool in  agartest can be useful for that).  Agar will not mark a window as "dirty" unless some GUI element in it  really needs to be redrawn. Unless you need to redraw things in a  non-standard way, your event loop only needs to call  AG_WindowDrawQueued(), and that will redraw any dirty window in the  application.  On 07/22/14 04:57, Antony Ranque wrote: </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Julien Nadeau</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2014-07-30T12:17:28</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/723">     <title>Unexpected rendering behavior with demo "customeventloop.c"</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/723</link>     <description><pre>   Dear all,    The port of agar on an embedded device (ARM) is almost done with opengl support (a reduce profile) and without SDL. My system doesn't have any OS or filesystem. We just have a couple of FrameBuffers, one active (what the screen display) and one inactive (where Agar and opengl draw).    To check the good behavior of the software I had tried to have my first window on the screen (custom eventloop demo with AG_LabelNew instead of AG_LabelNewPolled that did'nt work properly for me) but an unexpected thing occur :   - The rendering is done twice and only twice, I couldn't identify why the window is marked as "dirty" only once.   - The first rendering only display the three buttons in the upper right corner, the text and the button "Quit". No container of background for the window.   - The second rendering display correctly the window, with all the previously cited elements plus the container and background for the caption and the window itself.    I printed the OpenGL calls and they are exactly the same for the two rendering.    Any guesses of what happen? Or any infos about this behaviour in the docs? I would appreciate any help.    -Antony    _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html</pre></description>     <dc:creator>Antony Ranque</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2014-07-22T07:57:12</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/721">     <title>Re: Centos rpms?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/721</link>     <description><pre>On Mon, 20 Jan 2014 00:08:40 -0400 Julien Nadeau wrote:   Thanks for the information!  I have been knows to create a rpm of things that interest me if one doesn't already exist; I may look into doing that for agar.  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Frank Cox</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2014-01-20T05:51:11</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/720">     <title>Centos rpms?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/720</link>     <description><pre>I have just now started looking at the documentation for agar, and it looks like a grand new (to me) toy to play with.  I'm wondering if there are any Fedora or Centos rpms available for agar, or if I should try to create one myself.  I actually use Centos but can usually manage to recompile Fedora rpms to work on Centos as long as they don't get too weird.  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Frank Cox</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2014-01-19T16:20:03</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/719">     <title>Source</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/719</link>     <description><pre>Hello, I tried the two methods, they did not work. I tried using memcpy() on surface-&gt;pixels and it did not work, either. Am I missing sokething?  Thank you.  Code:  #include &lt;agar/core.h&gt;   #include &lt;agar/gui.h&gt;   #include &lt;cstdlib&gt;   #include &lt;iostream&gt;  using namespace std;  static AG_Window *win; static AG_Button *agb2; static AG_Style *style; static AG_Surface *surface; static AG_Pixmap *pxmp; static char *pixels = (char*) malloc(404000); static void *obj; static AG_DataSource *ds;  void agbuttonhandler(AG_Event *event){ cout&lt;&lt;"Hi!"&lt;&lt;endl; exit(1); }  void btn2_click(AG_Event *event){ int i; for (i=1; i&lt;=4000; i++){ *(pixels + i) = 250; } surface = AG_ReadSurface (ds, AG_PixelFormatRGBA (24, 8, 8, 8, 8)); AG_PixmapUpdateCurrentSurface  (pxmp); } /* AG_WriteSurface: CRASH */  /* Timer did not work, documentation seems WIP */  int main(int argc, char *argv[]) { int i;          AG_InitCore("myname", 0);         AG_InitGraphics(NULL);         win = AG_WindowNew(AG_WINDOW_PLAIN);         AG_LabelNew(win, 0, "Custom color scheme...");         AG_ButtonNewFn(win, 0, "foo", (&amp;agbuttonhandler), "%s", "world"); agb2 = (AG_ButtonNewFn(win, 0, "bar", (&amp;btn2_click), "%s", "Jupiter"));  surface = AG_SurfaceFromPixelsRGBA(pixels, 100, 100, 24, 8, 8, 8, 8);  for (i=1; i&lt;=10000; i++){ *(pixels + i) = 100; } pxmp = AG_PixmapFromSurfaceCopy (win, 0, surface);  *(pixels + 400) = '\\0';  AG_SurfaceResize (surface, 100, 100);         AG_WindowShow(win); ds = AG_OpenCore (pixels, 4000); //AG_DataSourceInit (ds);          AG_EventLoop();         AG_Destroy();         return (0); } _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Newuser 1972</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-12T09:21:30</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/718">     <title>Agar AG_Surface() or some other widget for direct pixelaccess in memory.</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/718</link>     <description><pre>Hello, I have been trying to use an AG_Surface as a direct renderer from pixel data in memory.  AG_Surface * AG_SurfaceRGBA (Uint w, Uint h, int bitsPerPixel, Uint flags, Uint32 Rmask, Uint32 Gmask, Uint32 Bmask, Uint32 Amask) was created and initialized and was then set to AG_Surface * AG_ReadSurface (AG_DataSource *ds) Where ds was malloc'd by using char declaration. When the the ds is set to the surface, it crashed.  Simply accessing the memory region did not work well. A loop like for (i=1;i&lt;=100;i++){        *(pixel + i) = 250; } where pixel is malloc'd as char did not produce any visible result. It was loaded by AG_SurfaceFromPixelsRGBA AG_PixmapUpdateSurface did not work, either.  Any recommendations/advices?  Thank you  Regards, R _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Newuser 1972</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-11T18:11:15</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/717">     <title>Agar AG_Style() is not working properly at runtime</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/717</link>     <description><pre>Hello, I was trying to use AG_Style interface during runtime and after many attempts, tried Declaring a style object.  Setting the style using AG_Style resulted in a compile error and the other resulted in a crash. The Style API seems to be declared in some different way than shown in the manual. That manpage was not there but there was a reference somewhere in the manual which I do not remember now.  Is there any other way to change styles (e.g. change button color at runtime)? It would be better if precompiled binaries of the styling/style editor is available for windows. And, the manual page for Style seems to be broken.  Thank you.  Regards, R _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-FPEHb7Xf0XWpxCrVjSmSkw&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Newuser 1972</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-11T04:07:09</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/716">     <title>Re: new user with issues running tests/demos</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/716</link>     <description><pre>Hi Sebastian,  Can you forward me the error message you've received from the list?  The next stable version will be released shortly, for now I recommend  that you try out the current (subversion) sources: http://dev.hypertriton.com/agar/trunk  There were many fixes made since the last release including MacOS X  related fixes, and a native Cocoa driver was implemented so that SDL  (sdlfb/sdlgl) are no longer the only available drivers in OSX. That  should fix the "No graphics drivers are available" error you're seeing.  The demos are no longer in ./demos, those were moved to the agar test  suite (agartest) under ./tests.  On 12/07/13 00:29, Sebastian Shader wrote: </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Julien Nadeau</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-07T05:52:12</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/715">     <title>test</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/715</link>     <description><pre>test, please ignore </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Julien Nadeau</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-07T05:50:45</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/714">     <title>new user with issues running tests/demos</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/714</link>     <description><pre>Hello list, I'm new to programming and Agar. I successfully downloaded and compiled Agar with no errors, however when attempting to run the test in the "Installing Agar on MacOS X" section control of the program simply returns to the prompt without doing anything. I did have to modify the call to main because I got the error "second parameter of main must be of type char **" so I did modify it to char **.  I also get a segmentation fault 11 EXC_BAD_ACCESS (SIGSEGV) when doing just "./hello" and not "sudo ./hello"? is this normal? here are my agar-config --cflags: -I/usr/local/include/agar   -I/usr/local/Cellar/freetype/2.5.1/include/freetype2   - I/usr/local/Cellar/libpng/1.5.17/include/libpng15  and --libs: -L/usr/lib64 -L/usr/local/lib -lag_gui -lag_core  -L/usr/local/Cellar/freetype/2.5.1/lib -lfreetype -lz -lbz2 -lpng15 -framework OpenGL -lm -L/usr/local/lib -ljpeg -L/usr/local/Cellar/libpng/1.5.17/lib -lpng15 -lpthread I'm on OSX 10.9  another issue is that whenever I run a demo (which configures and compiles fine) I get: "No graphics drivers are available"  thank you,  -Sebastian  p.s. as a final unrelated technical difficulty the mail kept getting returned when I sent it to the list over email </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Sebastian Shader</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-12-07T04:29:08</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/713">     <title>Re: Problem with events in "agarsdl.exe -o"</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/713</link>     <description><pre>Forget my last message, I solved all problems with the following change in "drv_sdl_common.c" (found in SVN last versions of this source file) :  .... /* Standard processEvent() method for SDL drivers. */ int AG_SDL_ProcessEvent(void *obj, AG_DriverEvent *dev) { ....     if (agWindowToFocus != NULL) {                                        // LINE TO ADD         AG_WM_CommitWindowFocus(agWindowToFocus);    // LINE TO ADD         agWindowToFocus = NULL;                                            // LINE TO ADD     }                                                                                            // LINE TO ADD         return (rv); } ....   a+ J-C </pre></description>     <dc:creator>JC</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-10-19T19:28:30</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/712">     <title>Re: Problem with events in "agarsdl.exe -o"</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/712</link>     <description><pre>Thanks for your answer.  I found that if I comment some lines in "drv_sdl_common.c" / "ProcessInputEvent(...)" / "case AG_DRIVER_MOUSE_BUTTON_UP :" so the callback functions of the buttons of my soft work. But there are still problems to focus the text areas. I continue to search.   Lines to comment : \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd if (agWindowToFocus != NULL || \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd !TAILQ_EMPTY(&amp;agWindowDetachQ)) { \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdAG_ObjectUnlock(win); \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdreturn (1); \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd}    JC    ________________________________  De\ufffd\ufffd: Paul A. Patience</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-10-10T18:34:59</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/708">     <title>Problem with events in "agarsdl.exe -o"</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/708</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  I have compiled agar from SVN trunk r9625 with msys/mingw, when I launch "test/agarsdl.exe -g" no problem. But when I launch "test/agarsdl.exe -o" (in overlay mode) the events are not normally managed : \ufffd\ufffd - cannot focus on the text zone \ufffd\ufffd - cannot close the window  I have the same kind of problems in my application when I use agar svn head (AG_ButtonNewFw do never launch my callback functions), but no problem with the 1.4.1 precompiled version.  Can anyone test the agarsdl test in overlay mode, I would like to know if the problem comes from the msys/mingw compilation.  I use SDL 1.2.15. _______________________________________________ Agar mailing list Agar-xWq8P/a1moLx9BLsLxWUfA&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org http://libagar.org/lists.html </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Jean-Claude Vogel</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-10-10T17:45:45</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/707">     <title>agar test suite and bsdbuild bugs</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/707</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  The agar test suite fails to compile because M_MatInvert44p, M_MatMult44Vector3, M_MatMult44Vector3p, M_MatMult44Vector4 and M_MatMult44Vector4p do not currently exist. I realize that this may be normal since I am using the svn sources.  Also, I wanted to report a `bug' in bsdbuild. I would post it on the bsdbuild mailing list, but it's not as active as this one.  When checking for NROFF, we do not break from the loop through PATH as soon as we find an executable. This means if any other executables are found, the last one is used. In case the final executable is not mandoc-compatible, no manual pages are generated.  If this is not on purpose, other checks at risk are those for msgfmt, ectags and ctags.  Index: BSDBuild/Builtins.pm =================================================================== --- BSDBuild/Builtins.pm        (revision 1006) +++ BSDBuild/Builtins.pm        (working copy) &lt; at &gt;&lt; at &gt; -34,6 +34,7 &lt; at &gt;&lt; at &gt;  for path in `echo $PATH | sed 's/:/ /g'`; do         if [ -x "${path}/nroff" ]; then                 NROFF="${path}/nroff" +               break         fi  done  if [ "${NROFF}" != "" ]; then  -- pap </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul A. Patience</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-10-08T22:44:32</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/706">     <title>[patch] gui/AG_Widget.3</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/706</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  I have found an error in AG_Widget(3). Patch follows:  Index: AG_Widget.3 =================================================================== --- AG_Widget.3(revision 9625) +++ AG_Widget.3(working copy) &lt; at &gt;&lt; at &gt; -82,9 +82,9 &lt; at &gt;&lt; at &gt;  .Bd -literal  typedef struct ag_widget_class {  struct ag_object_class _inherit; -void (*draw)(AG_Widget *w); -void (*size_request)(AG_Widget *w, AG_SizeReq *req); -int  (*size_allocate)(AG_Widget *w, const AG_SizeAlloc *alloc); +void (*draw)(void *); +void (*size_request)(void *, AG_SizeReq *); +int  (*size_allocate)(void *, const AG_SizeAlloc *);  } AG_WidgetClass;  .Ed  .Pp  -- pap </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul A. Patience</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2013-10-07T06:52:57</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/705">     <title>Re: MinGW MSYS ./configure problem</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.agar.general/705</link>     <description><pre>Hello,  I solved the problem by correcting the "gen-declspecs.pl" file in the case of two successive #define tag. at &gt;hypertriton.com" &lt;agar-xWq8P/a1moLx9BLsLxWUfA&lt; at &gt;public.gmane.org&gt;  Envoy\ufffd\ufffd le : Samedi 31 ao\ufffd\ufffdt 2013 11h37 Objet\ufffd\ufffd: [Agar] MinGW MSYS ./configure problem     Hello,  I'm trying to compile the agar SVN trunk in order to get the corrected "console.c". In SVN I can see :  In "agar-trunk/core/load_string.h" line 14 :  #define\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdAG_ReadString(nb) \\ \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdAG_ReadStringLen((nb),AG_LOAD_STRING_MAX) #define\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdAG_ReadStringv(nb,s) \\ \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdAG_ReadStringLenv((nb),AG_LOAD_STRING_MAX,(s))  But after the "./configure" execution I have in "agar-trunk\\include\\agar\\core\\load_string.h" line 14 : #define AG_ReadString(nb) \\  #define AG_ReadStringv(nb,s) \\  \ufffd\ufffdAG_ReadStringLen((nb),AG_LOAD_STRING_MAX) AG_ReadStringLenv((nb),AG_LOAD_STRING_MAX,(s)) void AG_WriteString(AG_DataSource *, const char *);    As you can see the first #define is directly followed by the second one, and the value of the first is after the second #define...  Of course, if I change the original load_string.h to suppress the newline and backslash associated I get the same problem with a lot of other header files.  Do you know which would be the source of the problem, Msys, MinGW or Agar ?
